awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Count/Mass Distinction in Native and Non-Native Grammar
awd_abstract_narration:
Language and cognition are deeply related, influencing each other in both universal and language-specific ways. This dissertation project aims to examine the relationship between the cognitive object/substance distinction and the linguistic count/mass distinction. More specifically, this project investigates how English, Korean and Mandarin Chinese speakers use and interpret count vs. mass nouns in their native languages and how Korean-speaking and Mandarin-speaking learners of English as a second language use and interpret count and mass nouns in English. This project aims to provide insights into what is universal and what is language-specific in the domain of the count/mass distinction. This project also has the potential to inform educators, language teaching professionals and developers of language teaching software about learners' use of the count/mass distinction.

To meet its goals, this dissertation research will first investigate the relationship between the object/substance interpretation and the grammar of the count/mass distinction in English, Korean and Mandarin. Once the properties of the count/mass distinction in all three languages are established, this research will examine how Korean-speaking and Mandarin-speaking learners of English interpret different types of English nouns, as well as how they judge and process English plural marking (a marker of the count/mass distinction), in both offline and online (reaction-time) tasks. This project will contribute to the fields of theoretical linguistics and psycholinguistics by providing information on grammatical knowledge and processing in both native and non-native language. Furthermore, this project enhances the understanding of the grammars of East Asian languages, specifically Korean and Mandarin Chinese.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated 1) the relationship between count/mass morphosyntax and the cognitive object/substance contrast in English and in two Generalized Classifier languages (Korean and Mandarin) to determine universal vs. language-specific aspects of the count/mass distinction; 2) the role of cross-linguistic transfer in the second language (L2) acquisition of the English count/mass distinction by Korean-/and Mandarin-speaking L2-learners of English; and 3) what these learners know about the English count/mass distinction at both explicit and implicit levels by using both online and offline methodologies. 

To address project goal 1, a minimal parts identification task, a controlled elicited production task, and a Grammaticality judgment task were administered to native speakers of English, Korean and Mandarin Chinese in their native languages. These experiments established the relevant morphosyntactic facts in English, Korean and Mandarin Chinese and allowed us to see how interpretations of different types of entities are related to the count/mass morphosyntax in these languages. To investigate the project goals 2 and 3, a self-paced reading task and a grammaticality judgment task were administered to L1-Korean and L1-Chinese L2-English learners, as well as native English controls, in a psycholinguistic lab. 

The results for native speakers of English, Korean and Mandarin Chinese suggest that perception of objects (e.g., chair) and substances (e.g., water) are universally aligned across languages. The results show that native speakers of English, Korean and Mandarin Chinese all had similar judgments for object-denoting nouns and substance-denoting nouns.

It was found that second language learners (mis)analyze nouns that are flexible cross-linguistically (spinach, peas) as flexible in English. Learners map objects (‘chair’) to count nouns, and substances (‘sunlight’) to mass nouns. Flexible nouns can denote either substances (the food-substance in spinach/pea/chocolate) or objects (a bunch of spinach, a single pea, a chocolate), hence learners allow them to occur in either count (plural) or mass (bare singular) form. Even though Korean but not Chinese has (optional) plural marking with inanimate nouns, we did not find evidence for native-language transfer in the data: both learner groups allowed plural marking with object-denoting nouns. Learners’ performance is traceable to the mapping between the conceptual system and the morphosyntax.

The results of this project have theoretical implications for the understanding of L2 acquisition and of L2 sentence processing, as well as for the syntax/semantics of the count/mass distinction cross-linguistically. Although prior research has only focused either on the interpretation of nouns as object- vs. substance- denoting, or on their morphosyntax as count vs. mass this research brings interpretation and morphosyntax together, using a novel combination of tasks to investigate the relationship between the object/substance interpretation and the count/mass morphosyntax cross-linguistically, as well as in L2- acquisition. Furthermore, this research is the first of its kind to directly investigate the role of L1-transfer in the L2-acquisition of the English count/mass distinction by L2-learners from two different Generalized Classifier languages (Korean and Mandarin), which differ in how they encode the count/mass distinction. Finally, this research made an important contribution to the understanding of what L2-learners know about the count/mass distinction at explicit vs. implicit levels, by comparing online and offline performance. 

Broader impacts: by examining the source of difficulty in L2-acquisition of the count/mass distinction, this project has potential implications for second language pedagogy when teaching the count/mass distinction in English. The results of this project have relevance for how the count/mass distinction is taught in the second language classroom. Furthermore, the methodological innovations in this project made a critical and timely contribution to the study of L2-acquisition and L2-processing,.
